title: 108_hr2061
content: The Act is titled the "National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Reauthorization Act of 2003" and includes general improvements to the national anti-drug media campaign. The Drug-Free Media Campaign Act of 1998 is amended to the National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act, focusing on preventing drug abuse among young people in the United States, increasing awareness of the impact of drug abuse, and encouraging parental involvement. The National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign Act aims to prevent drug abuse among young people, increase awareness of its impact, and encourage parental involvement. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug Free America, determines the overall strategy of the national media campaign. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug Free America, is responsible for determining the overall strategy of the national media campaign and approving all advertising used in the campaign. The Director, in consultation with the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, is responsible for the strategy and advertising of the national media campaign. The Partnership will recommend strategies and create advertising for the campaign. The national media campaign goals include addressing national, regional, and local drug threats, creating advertising for the campaign, except for specific cases outlined in the legislation. The Director will contract a media buying contractor to plan and purchase advertising time and space for the national media campaign, including testing all advertisements for effectiveness and industry standards. The Director will contract a media buying contractor to plan and purchase advertising time and space for the national media campaign, ensuring that the advertisements meet industry-accepted standards. Amendments are made to subparagraphs to update language and specify the Office of National Drug Control Policy or its designee for certain tasks. The Director will allocate funds for the national media campaign under section 106, requiring a no cost match of equivalent value of advertising broadcast time or in-kind contributions before executing a contract for advertising time or space. The Director must ensure that all no cost matches or in-kind contributions for the national media campaign relate to substance abuse prevention. Advertising material donated at no cost is exempt from sponsorship identification requirements. The Director must ensure that a minimum of 85% of funds appropriated for the national media campaign are used for advertising time and space, with a cap of $5,000,000 for developing advertising material each fiscal year. The national media campaign must allocate a minimum of 85% of funds for advertising time and space, with a yearly cap of $5,000,000 for developing advertising material. SEC. 104. FINANCIAL AND PERFORMANCE ACCOUNTABILITY. The Director is required to conduct audits and examinations of records as specified in the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act. An independent entity must evaluate the effectiveness of the national media campaign annually using data from various studies and publications. The Director must evaluate the national media campaign annually using data from studies like the Attitude Tracking Study and the National Household Survey on Drug Abuse, and submit a report to Congress. The Director must submit an annual report to Congress detailing the national media campaign's strategy, accomplishments, efficiency, advertising plans, responsible fund usage, and contracts with external entities. Authorization of appropriations for the Office of National Drug Control Policy is set at $195,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008.
